clean_story:
A divided city. A symbol of freedom. The Berlin Wall was a physical barrier that split East and West Berlin from 1961 to 1989. It was built by the German Democratic Republic (East Germany) to stop its citizens from fleeing to the West. 

People often think of the Berlin Wall as just a wall, but it was much more than that. It was a heavily guarded border with watchtowers, guard dogs, and even a "death strip" where soldiers were ordered to shoot anyone trying to escape. Despite this, over 5,000 people managed to cross the wall, some using creative methods like tunnels, hot air balloons, or even sewer pipes. 

The fall of the Berlin Wall began with a mistake. On November 9, 1989, a government official announced that East Germans could freely travel to the West, but he didn’t realize his words would trigger a mass exodus. Thousands of people gathered at the wall, demanding to be let through. Overwhelmed, the guards finally opened the gates, and the wall began to crumble. 

The fall of the Berlin Wall was a turning point in history. It marked the beginning of the end of the Cold War and led to the reunification of Germany in 1990. Today, remnants of the wall serve as a reminder of the struggle for freedom and the power of peaceful protest. 

Three related subjects are the impact of the Cold War on global politics, the role of peaceful protests in shaping history, and the stories of those who risked everything to escape the East.
